June 8, 2021 X Facebook Linkedin Copy link Free Website Traffic Checker Discover your competitors' strengths and leverage them to achieve your own success Analyze Traffic You‚Äôve scheduled a discovery call. Awesome. You‚Äôre on your way to bringing in a new customer or client and making a sale ‚Äì but before you get started, you need to ask yourself a few questions to guarantee that your call will knock the socks off the person on the other end of the line. Discovery calls, after all, are a crucial part of your sales strategy, sales funnel and buyer‚Äôs journey. In this blog post, we‚Äôll take a look at what discovery calls are, how to prepare for a discovery call, and which mistakes you probably want to avoid making. We‚Äôve also got a handy discovery call checklist for you ‚Äì just call it the cherry on top. üçí What is a discovery call? Discovery calls for a buyer are similar to trying on new clothes or shoes before purchasing them in the store. You know you like them, you think you want to buy them, but you‚Äôre not entirely sure. What will convince you to take the plunge and pull out your credit card? Trying them on for size. The same decision-making goes into discovery calls. The goal is to see if you (the service provider) and the buyer are a potentially good fit for one another. It‚Äôs the chance for both of you to try each other on, to see if you understand each other‚Äôs needs, goals, priorities, and problems, and whether you can help the buyer solve their issues. üëï Over a third of salespeople in a recent survey said prospecting is sales teams‚Äô biggest challenge when it comes to B2B sales. And discovery calls are an important part of a (efficient) sales prospecting process ‚Äì after all, you don‚Äôt have the time for customers that aren‚Äôt a good fit for your business (or don‚Äôt want you) being caught up in your net. But it‚Äôs not just a matter of luck. The fate of a discovery call can be highly dependent on how well prepared you are, the value you bring to the call, and the discussion that‚Äôs generated between you. At the end of your call, your goal should be for your potential client to say to themselves: ‚ÄúYes! That‚Äôs what I need‚Äù. Next step: following up with the right sales-enablement content. Short on time or just prefer video learning? Watch our two minute guide to crushing your next discovery call. What are the steps towards an effective discovery call? A discovery call is not just a spur-of-the-moment kind of deal. You need to be prepared, know what‚Äôs on the agenda for the call, guide the call in the right direction, and be prepared for any curveballs and questions that may come your way. Let‚Äôs take a look at the four key steps to a successful discovery call: Step #1: Plan your discovery call One of the most important parts of a discovery call is to provide value to your potential buyer and decision-maker. Sure, you probably have a website and social media presence that they can check out, but in your call, you need to expand and tailor it to them. What can you add that will wow your prospect? What information can you give them; what problem of theirs can you solve; what idea can you throw their way? This is all stuff that you need to think about during your discovery process, before hopping on a phone call. First, research the other side. Who are they? What is their role? What problem are they looking to solve? This is information that can usually be found online, (using digital tools such as Similarweb‚Äôs Sales Intelligence) or you can have potential call participants fill out a quick questionnaire, helping you focus on the right things during the call. Check out our discovery call checklist to help you get started on planning. Step #2: Start by quickly reviewing your call agenda Once you‚Äôre both on the line (yes, yes, it‚Äôs important to actually pick up the phone), take a moment to outline what‚Äôs about to happen. Why? People are busy today. You are, and your potential client most certainly is. No one wants to waste time or have their time wasted. By outlining your agenda for the call, your prospect will feel that you‚Äôre respecting their time and that you‚Äôre well prepared. Start by letting the buyer know who you are, what you do, a bit about yourself so that they feel comfortable. It‚Äôs also important to let them know what you‚Äôre going to discuss, and what the end goal of the call is. We recommend letting the prospect know that the call is purely informational to make sure you‚Äôre a good fit for one other. This takes a bit of the pressure off, which is always welcome. Step #3: Use sales discovery calls effectively When done right, you can use your discovery calls to: 1. Qualify your buyer In this step, you‚Äôll set the ground to see if you and the buyer are a good potential fit. You‚Äôll want to do this by asking a set of questions (which you have, of course, prepared in advance) and getting to know them better. These questions will help you understand pain points, competition, goals, results, current business models, and processes. Don‚Äôt go nuts here. If you ask your client 25 questions in a row, they‚Äôll start feeling overwhelmed. It‚Äôs best to ease into things. No need for a discovery call script but having an outline should help. 2. Identify your buyer‚Äôs issues and surface areas of opportunity This is your time to shine. Figure out the issues that your buyer is having and provide value. Show them that you are the person to solve their issues and make their dreams come true. Some business owners are nervous about this phase of a discovery call. They don‚Äôt want to give away their secrets right away. But by giving small insights into the work you can do with a potential client, you‚Äôll be on the way to igniting something inside them to make them want to purchase. After all, they have a problem, and you have the solution. What‚Äôs better than that? By surfacing the areas of opportunity you can provide during a discovery call, you can genuinely help your leads understand why they should work with you in the future. 3. Open up a discussion about the end results and schedule your next steps Give your potential buyer time to talk in the discovery call. Don‚Äôt forget that this process is all about seeing if you‚Äôre a good mutual fit. By allowing your customer the chance to talk, discussing end results and where they are going, they‚Äôll begin to feel more comfortable as well as dedicated to the process. Don‚Äôt forget to discuss your next steps and even schedule if the buyer feels comfortable at this stage. Don‚Äôt be afraid to get a bit ‚Äúsalesy‚Äù here. After all, your goal is to make the sale! Step #4: Be ready to improvise on the fly You‚Äôve prepared everything, you know the flow of your discovery call, and you‚Äôve got your sales discovery questions lined up and ready to go. But most things in life don‚Äôt go according to plan. And your discovery call most likely won‚Äôt either. Don‚Äôt fret, this can be a good thing. You‚Äôre an expert in your field, and you know your stuff. Now be ready to improvise when necessary. If your buyer throws a question into the mix that you weren‚Äôt exactly prepared for, don‚Äôt panic. Just answer precisely how you know how. Good discovery call questions and mistakes to avoid As we‚Äôve mentioned, you should create a list of questions for your discovery call before hitting ‚Äúcall‚Äù. There are some qualifying questions that are relevant to most businesses: What are your goals? What are your pain points? What software do you use? What does your budget look like? What are your clients using you for? You get the vibe. But, the best questions are the ones that are specific and relevant to your target audience and their needs. Only you know what those are. To summarize, these are the do‚Äôs when preparing for your discovery call: ‚úîÔ∏è Come prepared with the right questions ‚úîÔ∏è Research your prospect ‚úîÔ∏è Be concise ‚úîÔ∏è Ask smart questions ‚úîÔ∏è Make your prospect feel they‚Äôre unique There are also quite a few mistakes that you‚Äôll want to avoid when planning your sales discovery questions. These include: ‚ùå Making your prospect feel they‚Äôre being interrogated ‚ùå Sticking to your discovery call checklist and not allowing yourself flexibility ‚ùå Talking too much ‚ùå Asking yes or no questions instead of open-ended questions ‚ùå Getting too much into the pricing ‚ùå Not doing enough research By avoiding these common mistakes, you‚Äôll be sure to be on the fast track to success on your next call. Successful discovery calls: The key to bringing in new, relevant customers We‚Äôve taken a look at what a discovery call looks like for sales professionals and why being prepared with the right discovery call questions is so important for securing a sales opportunity.
